38913134.review: If you run linux for gaming, do not get this game. The only way to complete it, is to save everytime you complete anything, close out the game all the way to steam, wait for it to synchronize, then go back in. Otherwise once you get to between 3 and 4 hours of total game play, it will crash, it will corrupt the game save, and you will start over. I won't be buying another image form game as all I got was "If it's happening repeatedly there's nothing we can do" after having it occur twice at roughly the 4 hour mark. Enjoyed the gameplay and story, support was subpar, and restarted 3 times. Oh and the final boss glitched out, closed me all the way out of steam right as I defeated it, so I had to do it again. No replay value, and no value in getting any other image form games.

38840381.review:
There is an okay game burried beneath this really unpolished game. Unfortunately you have to deal with some really floaty controls, some god awful level design. Then you'll be dealing with some absolutely absurd gameplay mechanics. I hope you'll enjoy going back to the hub area over and over again just to refil your lanturn and water because the game thinks you'll enjoy doing that for most of the game. You'll die a ton from enemies and falling rocks, and you'll probably find treasure seeking more frustrating than fun.  Also the end game content is beyond garbage, prepare to endure some absolutely horrendous, bullshit hard levels that only people who enjoy playing Cup Head with boxing gloves on will enjoy.

If you think this game might be up your alley, it's probably worth $8 at most, and that's if you're willing to tollerate what I listed above. The $20 list price is outrageous for this junk, it's clear Image and Form learned absolutely nothing from the first installment (Which I played on the 3DS). Terrible controls, terrible level design, extremely convoluted secrets. At the very least I can say I could convince myself to beat it, but that's not good enough to recommend it. There is ZERO replay value here, this is a poor sequel that just repeats all the mistakes the first game made.

If you want a good metroidvania game, go play Hollow Knight instead, it's a MUCH better game than this.

SCORE: 9/10

First off, Steamworld is an amazing universe. Image and Form have crafted it with love and humor, and I've really enjoyed my time in it. Steamworld Dig 1 and 2 were both polished game loops that were just fun. Steamworld Heist blew me away because it really was XCOM in 2D, but much cuter, funnier, and more fair. Steamworld Dig 2 is a great sequel because it improves on the first one in every way AND doesn't overstay its welcome with padding. 38758856.review:
Short version:  Simple fun.
==================

Long version:
----------

The good:
- The controls are responsive.  The character is fun to control.
- Very little is just handed to you.  Your upgrades feel like you have earned them, which is satisfying.
- The upgrades feel impactful as soon as you get them.  Progress feels good.
- The colors and areas are vibrant except for Vectron, the machine place (Fair warning: that place can be a tad scary).  Areas stretch on for a bit, but they've put in good effort to vary up the locales.
- The map is simple but is easy to use.

Mixed:
 - Not exactly difficult.  Most of the fun comes from exploration and remembering places that you can access with later upgrades.
- While there is a bonus for finding all of the collectables, there is only one ending.

The bad:
- I mentioned that some of the areas stretch on for a bit.  I got slightly lost a few times just from the sheer expanse of the tunnels.
- The plot is probably the weakest point.  You start off with a simple yet adequate story of "Find your friend.  He was last seen at this place."  Nothing wrong with that, but the culmination to the ending lacks any real sense of "OH SNAP.  S*** IS GETTING REAL." except for a single prompt before the final boss that says you won't be able to go back.

In summary:
Though the abrupt ending will probably leave you wanting more, you want more for a reason.  The gameplay feels good all around.

38733266.review:
Mining games are usually about making successive trips into the underground. Haul back a few loads of ore, and get equipment that allows you to dig deeper, haul back even more, stay down longer, etc. In Steamworld Dig 2, the mining is almost superficial. This is because the game layers one mechanic on top of another in steady beats, always opening up new options. Digging for gems is sort of a side-show that allows you to keep on upgrading all this gear you unlock. 

The story is neat and ties into the whole Steamworld universe, but is self contained enough to allow you to play it without having played its predecessor or other Steamworld games. Each objective sends you deeper into one of its shafts, which you were inclined to do anyway for the precious gems. But each area is hand-crafted and designed to challenge you with the different tools you get. 

Can you use the water bombs to their fullest potential to reach secrets? What options does the grappling hook open up? In true metroidvania style, you will pass areas that need a tool you don't have yet. But the vast majority of secrets are able to be discovered without needless backtracking. Which is great because once the loot is gone, it's gone. Handy fast travel points minimise the amount of time you need to be travelling to and from each area. 

In all, it's a wonderfully crafted adventure. So much more than just a mining game.

38726153.review:
I came into this as someone who enjoyed Steamworld Dig and thought it a fun little game with a fun twist on the genre. This is a more expansive title with greater emphasis on character building and hand crafted puzzle rooms. I found the experience a little too easy for my liking, but I was never lost interest in exploring the map. I think all of the mainpath upgrades are worthwhile and introduce new gameplay mechanics to keep the experience fresh for its entire duration. I'm a bit bummed that the vertical space isn't used very much. I still think combat is pretty weak, not sure why you can't use your melee weapon while jumping. Once I acquired the jetpack I went out to the open areas and explored to find a whole lotta nothing (save the endgame bonus room). All in all, I dug this title. It's a solid 12 hours if you explore thoroughly. 


Strengths

Character Progression - there's a far greater empahsis on upgrades and perks with which you can tool out your character for a given area/challenge

Exploration - handcrafted puzzle rooms are littered throughout the game world that, while on the easy side, make good use of your upgrades

Upgrades - new gameplay mechanics are introduced that open new avenues of exploration and keep the game feeling fresh throughout


Weakness

combat - while ranged combat feels solid, melee combat feels clunky and I don't know why you're not able to attack while jumping. 

veritcal space - severely underutilized. once I acquired the jetpack I was disappointed to learn that there were very few reasons to explore the vertical space in the outer areas

selling goods - having to come back and forht into town was grating in the early game. it reminded me of Torchlight and how that game allowed you to send a pet to sell your junk for you while you kept exploring. thankfully this became less of an issue once I was able to purchase the 

skill caps - I'm not sure locking certain perks behind levels/blueprints was a good idea, I would have much prefereed being able to select from all of the perks, that way I could save my points for something I really wanted 

invisible walls - this is mostly personal taste, but I'm not a fan of hiding secrets behind regular looking walls. anything that encoruages pixel hunting is a negative in my book. Thankfully, not all secrets are done in this manner

38677391.review:
SteamWorld Dig 2 hugely expands on everything that was good about the first one. It's exceptionally well-crafted and very fun to play. There's so much to explore and do. The variety in the locales and surprise secrets are awesome. All of the secrets are tricky to find but they're always subtly telegraphed so you're not just wandering around looking for fake walls, and there are powerups that help. The ability progression is really awesome, and by the end you're a mining superhero, which was super fun. 

The only con is the story is rather weak; there's a lot of text dialogue but very little of it is interesting or plot-related. I don't think it detracts from the experience at all though. One minor nitpick is that (like many games) the game ends quite soon after you get all of the awesome abilities; I would have appreciated a bit more game play being an ALL POWERFUL MINER.

This is "overwhelmingly positive" for a reason. Top notch, highly recommended.

38664815.review:
Mit einem Wort: großartig! Steamworld Dig war für mich anfangs ein Gelgenheitskauf für den Nintendo 3DS und wurde schnell zu einem der meistgespielten Titel dort. Grund war das einfache Gameplay kombiniert mit Graben / Geldverdienen / Upgrades und ein paar Knobelpassagen. 
Als nun der zweite Teil erschien, war klar: das Spiel muss her und um das Fazit gleich vornewegzunehmen: ich wurde nicht enttäuscht. 
Aber was macht das Spiel für mich denn nun zum Highlight? Nachfolgend werde ich diese Frage in mehreren Kategorien beantworten.
---
1. Das Spielprinzip
Wie schon in Teil 1 ist es eine Mischung aus Jump'n'Run, Erkundung (Mining), Beute sammeln und Upgraden, um weiter voranzukommen. Diese Mischung wurde komplett beibehalten und erinnert mich an die 2D-Klassiker Metroid.
2. Das Leveldesign
Die Levels bestehen im Grunde aus einer einzigen großen Karte / Spielwelt mit verschiedenen Arten, sei es Wüste, eine wildwuchernde Pflanzenwelt, eine höllische Lavaumgebung oder ein technisiertes, futuristisches Szenario, genannt Vectron. Man beginnt an der Oberfläche und gräbt sich im Laufe des Spiels immer tiefer ins Erdinnere vor und kann dabei mit allerhand technischen Hilfsmitteln den Untergrund durchbrechen, sei es die unverzichtbare Spitzhacke, ein Bohrer für härteres Gestein oder die neue praktische Haftbombe für Sprengungen außerhalb der Reichweite ersterer Werkzeuge.
DIe Levels sind dabei nichtlinear, d.h. man betritt die meisten Areale mehrfach und bekommt dank Spielefortschritt und Upgrades nun Zugang zu bisher verschlossenen oder verbrogenen Bereichen.
Erschwert wird die Suche durch allerhand feindliches Gesindel, wie Käfer, Insekten, Magier(!) und sonstigem Getier, die alle mit unterschiedlichen Agriffsmustern aufwarten.
Hinzu kommen noch fallenartige Einrichtungen, wie etwa gefährliche Flüssigkeiten, explodierende Fässer oder herabfallende Steinbrocken.
Praktischerweise entdeckt man in regelmäßigen Abständen Transportröhren zurück in die Stadt, wo man seine Ressourcen auffüllt und das gesammelte Zeug zu Geld macht.  
3. Das Sammeln
Wie in Teil 1 wird fleißig Diamanten gesammelt und in der Stadt an der Oberfläche zu Geld gemacht. Damit lassen sich wiederum praktische Upgrades erwerben, die einem das Vorankommen deutlich erleichtern, wie etwa eine größere Tasche für mehr Beute, mehr Lebensenergie, verbesserte Ausrüstung oder einen größeren Wassertank. 
4. Das Erkunden
Abseits von den eigentlichen Zielen gibt es unzählige Türen und Geheimnisse zu entdecken. Erstere beinhalten wertvolle Bonusgegenstände, die man sich durch eine "Kobelkammer" teilweise hart erarbeiten muss und letztere findet man zufällig oder bei entsprechend guter Aufmerksamkeit.
5. Grafik und Sound
Mit einer tollen, stummungsvollen Musik, passender Geräuschekulisse und einer wunderbar gezeichnetenm, bunten, effektvollen 2D-Grfaik ist das Spiel einfach hervorragend umgesetzt.
6. Die Steuerung
Mit einame Gamepad lässt sich das Spiel präzise steuern und dank der Möglichkeit, einen Sprung in der Luft noch mal nachzujustieren, sind pixelgenaue Landungen möglich. Ab und an werden diese auch abverlang. 
Probleme hatte ich hier nur mit der Kombination Wurfhaken + Klattersprung und anschließendem Richtungswechsel. Wer da in Hektik kommt, wird den einen oder anderen Sturz erleiden.
7. Die Bosse
Anders als in Teil 1 gibt es hier Zwischenbosse, die für etwas Auflockerung sorgen und der Endboss scheint im ersten Moment eine harte Nuss zu sein, ist aber mit etwas Konzentration gut zu meistern. 
---
Somit hat Steamworld Dig alles, was in Teil 1 gut funktioniert hat, übernommen und vieles hinzugefügt. Vor allem das Ausrüstungssystem wurde vielseitiger, da man nicht nur mit Geld, sondern auch mit Zahnrädern verbesserte Funktionen erzielen kann. 
Die lästigen Energiekugeln hingegen gibt es nicht mehr und man muss auch nicht allzu weite Wege gehen, da die Transportröhren deutlich häufiger vorkommen und somit auch der Teleporter überflüssig wird. 
Mit 7 Stunden für den ersten Durchlauf mit 36% gefundenen Geheimnissen und einem Bronzestern ist noch viel Luft nach oben für weitere Sessions. 
Alles in Allem finde ich das Prinzip super und kann es jedem empfehlen, der Spiele wie Boulder Dash, Metroid oder im weistesten Sinne auch Terraria mag (ohne Freeplay und Bauen natürlich).
Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist nicht allzu hoch, die Motivation aber dafür umso mehr. Solche Titel gehören gefördert, denn sie zeigen auf, was an Speilen früher toll war, bevor alle nur noch online spielen und ihr Geld für Zusatzinhalte (= vorenthaltene Inhalte) ausgeben wollten. Auch das muss mal gesagt werden.

Still good graphics. But games are not about only graphics, so nope, do not recommend, sorry.

38645386.review:
The original SteamWorld Dig is one of my favorite sit back & relax games. Its only drawback was that it felt more like a demo than a full game. I spent around 6 hours beating the original and I'm nearing that mark with the sequel but I've barely touched the subsurface of this game.

The sequel brings back the precise controls of the original. A vast network of locations to mine, explore & secret rooms to uncover. The upgrade system has been expanded to the point where you'll almost have to pick and choose as I don't think there are enough resources for all.

There's also a much wider array of enemies to contend with but like the first one, they aren't a major obstacle.

38601287.review:
I read somewhere that SteamWorld Dig 2 was sort of, just a little bit, like Spelunky. Heck yes, I love me some Spelunky, so gimme!

Suffice to say: the comparison is apt. In SW Dig 2 you run and jump around a world mostly constructed of blocks. You can mine some of the blocks, gather ores, then sell those for profit, which in turn can be used to purchase upgrades to help you get deeper into the game world. Over time you will uncover secrets, puzzle rooms and, obviously, the story of the game, along with several boss fights.

SteamWorld Dig 2 has a visual style of its own, a curious hand-drawn look, but as I played the game I began to feel that this type of visual style and the intense labour required to create content with it might have limited the game somewhat. Enemy types are sparse, animations simple and none of the enemies in the game, save for the last boss, offer any significant challenge combat-wise. Somehow I feel that these matters are linked to one another...

As for audio, the game sits steadily in the "functional, fine, but not really memorable" -category. The music lacks memorable melodies, but serves its purpose as a fine ambient accompaniment to the more laid back moments of adventure, or strolling around the small town, talking to the handful of NPC's. Voice acting, if you can call it that, harkens back to the good ole' Nintendo 64 -days, where characters talk in unique little squeaks, beeps, boops and such.

So what do they talk about then? What's the story? Well, you play as a blue robot called Dorothy, adventuring out to find your lost friend Rusty. Alas, Rusty has gone missing deep in the mines and so you are sent deep down to find him. Oh, and to bring back a bunch of valuables. Gotta earn your keep, eh? What follows is an occasionally comedic romp through mines, caverns, temples and other, more otherworldly, locales, as you follow one clue after another and, as is the case with these things, try to stop the world from ending as your side job. Easy-peasy!

While I can't say I played the game anywhere near to a 100% completion, let alone go for the more challenging modes on offer later in the game, I feel that I have to go back to the Spelunky comparison for a moment: SteamWorld Dig 2 is a more streamlined, designed, hand-crafted adventure. It has a clear beginning, middle and an end, and it relies fairly heavily on its story. As such, there is very limited replayability, and I doubt anyone, apart from the hardcore speedrunning crowd, will find more than maybe 10-12 hours of gameplay here. Nowhere near the hundred hours one can sink into something randomly generated like Spelunky.

Is that a good thing or a bad thing? That depends heavily on the player, really. Spelunky gives more bang for your buck, when it comes to raw hours of gameplay, and while it is a simpler game at its core, it gives the player more of a sensation of discovering things. SteamWorld Dig 2 on the other hand has more potential to give its player a few nice evenings of adventuring, digging and exploring, followed by a satisfying ending and a feeling of accomplishment one might not find in Spelunky even after months of playing.

If you ask me: Both are good games and well worth your time!


Playtime: 6+ hours (single playthrough)

Ratings (1-10)
Visual: 8
Audio: 7
Story: 7
Gameplay: 9
Overall: 8

38577902.review:
I do kind of recommend this game, but it teeters on a knife's edge. I've switched between the 'Yes' and 'No' button several times, but ultimately the price is too high for the length and the potential of the game is wasted.
I played SteamWorld Dig on the 3DS and SteamWorld Heist on the PC, the latter of which is a far stronger game than this title in almost every way.

The game is roughly 9 hours long if you spend at least some time looking for secrets. 
For 20€ that's way too short a game and it could've been made longer simply by adding more spaces to dig through, especially early on when you have to think over how to go about getting ore without any mistakes. There should've been more room to 'overfarm' ore and get all the upgrades and cogs to max out your character.

The pacing is kind of bad and the story is worse than in the first game and has a rushed conclusion. Fans of the first game probably remember Vectron fondly, but while it was featured nicely in Dig 2 the visit was all too brief.

Mechanically the game is fairly strong, the upgrades are interesting and while some of it is a repeat of the first Dig, most would accept that digging is the core part of these titles. Mechanically, my worst complaint is that the character floats too much in the air, which can be very frustrating in some areas.

For 10€ you could get Hollow Knight with its DLC's (which is an absolute steal!), or if you like alternative Metroidvania's then Song of the Deep is 15€ and nearly half again as long. 
While Dig is a relaxing platformer/metroidvania, the lack of challenge is sorely felt. Whether it detracts from the game is up to the player, it might simply be how the developers want it to be.

When I finished this title, it reminded me of when I played Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow, if you didn't have the correct item to pass the first 'ending'. Sadly, while in C:DoS you'd realize there was much more, Dig 2 ends somewhat abruptly and you wish you'd saved your money.
Despite the negatives, Dig 2 isn't a bad game, I just wish there was a lot more of it.

38575935.review:
I really liked this game, but I did have a few irritations, so I'll get those out of the way first...

I think the visual presentation is overly glossy, and doesn't really do justice to the *actual visual design* underlying it, which by contrast I quite liked (example: how much nicer does the title screen look than how things are rendered in-game?). and there are a few aspects of the controls which I suspect aren't as easy to use as they were meant to be, not to mention a puzzle area or two apparently designed by actual sadists, which force you to wallow in the mediocrity of specific aspects of the controls ("floor is lava" puzzle, looking at you. twice), rather than enjoying the parts of them which actually work well. as such, IMO this game could easily be doing a better job of playing to its strengths in these regards.

but those are basically my only real complaints, about a game which I'm otherwise finding to be very entertaining, engaging, rewarding, and also well-written, which is a rare bonus among games these days and one I really appreciate. and hey, it's always nice to see a female protagonist who doesn't appear to be any flavour of walking cliche, something which we still seem to struggle with producing.

the gameplay itself is a clever and (at least imo) somewhat innovative take on contemporary metroidvania-like games on the one hand, and contemporary boulderdash-like games such as spelunky et co on the other. there isn't a huge amount to add except simply that it's a well-designed and well-polished rendition of those basic concepts, along with a gear upgrades system and a reassignable customization interface which allow the player a large degree of agency over how they approach any particular area, even though which items you do or do not have depend on your progress through the game's plot.

between the clear thought and polish that have gone into mechanical gameplay concerns, the creative environment and character design, and the story and dialogue which have _clearly been written by actual writers_, this title is a clear standout against the flood of samey, uninspired drek which we on Steam are drowning in at present. and it does so in spite of being, mechanically speaking, a merger of two very well defined existing formats; this isn't hard to do when you have a world and a thematic concept which are original and which also map well to existing well-defined formats.

excellent work, from a studio I'll definitely be watching from now on. you folks are what keeps this industry, and this market, alive.

[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Improved upon everything from the first game
    [*]Game combat and movement is faster
    [*]World is bigger and open requiring a map now for non-linearity

[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]If you’ve played the first one, this is a must buy, its better in every way. The game might not still change those that don’t like the mining aspect of the game as it’s still the main gameplay loop.

    [*]Let’s get the bad out of the way first; they don’t have any music to listen to outside the game. The first one had the cool main menu theme, and SteamWorld heist had an entire album I bought. So nothing gameplay wise, unless the game being too easy would turn you off. (Restarts are counted as deaths somehow, died less than 10 times overall)

    [*]Overall the game is a vast improvement from the first game, from mechanics, pacing, amount of content and polish that I don’t feel bad spending near full price compared to getting the first for pennies. The mining aspect is what set it apart and the game doubled down on just making its levels, caves and abilities great instead of trying to fit in the normal metroidvania genre that most people think of. The game is unique with this style and can’t wait for what they come up with next in the SteamWorld series.
[/list]

[u]Compared to first game: [/u]
 [list]

    [*]The game starts out faster with you able to get important gear fast making the start not such a slow start compared to the first game and the game has double the content, more caves, bosses, secrets, all no filler and double the playtime from this expanded sequel.

    [*]You get new powers like a sticky bomb, grenade, jetpack and hook that work both as tools to move, mine and kill enemies.  Each with upgrades that are found in the world and some are optional. Old powers items like ladders and teleports are not needed and replaced with preset portals you have to reach.

    [*]The upgrade has added more options with money unlocking the straight upgrades needed to go farther down, but you now have cogs that you slot into vastly altering abilities ranging from simple to overpowered, like chance to get double resource, heal on kill, healing in pools, and cooling instantly your jetpack. You can’t have all of them and you have to choose what’s more important. You can re-slot them, so choices are not permanent.  There are probably 30 slots to fill, with the more powerful ones requiring more cogs to balance it. Some are only unlocked through milestones and secrets.

    [*]Speaking of secrets, the game has more complex secrets and harder to find ones since the abilities are different, keeping track of secrets is better as, on the map you have caves icon change when all secrets are found inside each area’s total amount displayed.

    [*]I forgot to mention they have a map, as the world is bigger and not linear and digging straight down the whole time. You have different hub locations that are on the horizontal and going from town to any location discovered is fast with zero load time and just a button press away.

    [*]Combat is the exact same as the first one, with some range with the jetpack and ranged weapons. Don’t expect any nuance that you might get in other metroidvania games. You do technically have 3 bosses, which the first was too simple for me to really consider one. Still at least double from the first game and overall better designed ones as well. Final boss is way better than the first one.

38538080.review:
Obviously there are some good parts to this game and it's got a lot of fans see reviews below. I however am not one of them and wanted to offer a balanced opinion for those on the fence about this purchase.

What is it?:
I would say it's a metroidvania, casual, cartoony, open-world, mining, platformer with a focus on puzzle solving, exploration, and simplfied combat.

What isn't it?:
Challenging, Original (in direct contrast to a certain popular websites reviewers stated opinion), Mechanically Sound, Long, or particularly deep.

The GOOD:
Constant Feel of Progression (Triple Star Here As I Believe This May be Why Many Love This Game and Overlook other Aspects)
Good-Balance (Helps and goes hand in hand with the first one) at least until you unlock a certain item and it seems to instantly break the game (which isn't necessairly a bad thing).
Bright and colorful world (the art does seem to be original and well done)
Exploration is consistently rewarding (prizes and unlockables galore)
If your looking for a true Casual Game it's probably going to be a winner
Easy Backtracking and frequent warp points (well pipes in game) make a difficult obstacle for this genre to overcome essentially null and void.

AC/DC:
Sound - Not my cup of tea but did not enchance or degrade the game for me
Length - If your not into exploring and just want to beat the pavement I think you could probably finish it in under 5 hours, however if you're going to explore you can probably squeeze 12 hours or so out of a single playthrough.
Plot - If your here for that it's probably best you go elsewhere...

The BAD:

Control - This is a platformer with stiff controls and awkward physics a cardinal sin in my gaming bible
Combat - It's repetitive which is okay except it's not challenging which makes it a bore. The exception here is for the challenge you will unnecessarily have controlling your character. It's an easy enough game that it won't jump out as being as unfair as other harder games that suffer from this issue but it's an annoyance some (obviously me) just won't be able to live with.
One path progression-Limited amount of customization, They try hard but honestly many of the upgrades are worthless and hurt this aspect of the game. It's also strange in that the World is pretty Open but your path through it seems extremely defined by the lackluster plot.
Challenge - Other than the standard setup of Metroidavnia roadblocks and finding a way around them I found the challenge here to be very lacking. It's a fine line to draw but I don't think I spent more than a minute or two on any one puzzle and they came off as uninteresting to me.
Plot - I mean it's there...If you really like cutesy cartoony characters perhaps the ones here and their limited amount of character traits will be of interest but there's nothing special about it. The best thing I can say is that most of the dialouge interactions are short.
Content to Cash Ratio - $20 dollars US when off sale seems a bit steep for this game. As a rule of thumb $1 for one hour played is what I'm expecting. Although with good polish and production values this game does lower the ratio I would need to feel content with my purchase.

Overall Rating 4.5/10

It's a logjam of different genres in a game and although it's handled here better than many others in terms of trying to make all those parts work together ultimately I won't recommend any game labeled a platformer that has such poor controls.

38245201.review:
SteamWorld Dig 2
by Image & Form
Genre: Metroidvania
Release: September 8, 2017

-----

I REALLY love Metroidvania games! Those awesome exploration fests that require additional abilities to go back and unlock new areas or get awesome new abilities are some of my favorite games ever. So, when I saw (belatedly, I’m sorry to say) that Swedish developer Image & Form had released a sequel to their amazing game which I also loved, SteamWorld Dig, I jumped on it as soon as possible!

Rusty, the protagonist of the first game, is missing! So, the merchant from that game, Dorothy, sets off in search of him. She ends up in El Machino, a town buffeted by earthquakes from deep beneath Archaea, the planetwide mine which was also a setting of the first game! The town’s mayor beckons you to go underground and see what the problem is, mainly so the economy can keep rolling rather than for any safety concerns (such a politician, heh). Dorothy obliges him, and so sets off on her quest…

She has a little spark friend, who provides her with a constantly-updating map of the surroundings, and this time, once it’s in place, it’s locked – there’s no procedural generation here, which means there is more potential for great puzzle action! And that potential is fulfilled, in spades! Quite a few dozen caves have many secrets waiting for you to discover them, but to get far in the world, you will of course have to collect new items…

and that’s where the Metroidvania comes in! From the start you’ll be able to wall-climb, but it becomes clear very soon that you’ll need more advanced equipment! So, you get equipped with pressure bombs for precision detonation of pesky, out-of-reach blocks; a jackhammer to smash through brick; a hookshot to speed through the treacherous caverns with ease; and much, much more! Also, you can collect cogs throughout the mines and other locales! These can be installed on your equipment using the workbench up in town, and provide all kinds of interesting and useful effects!

Keep your lantern full of fuel at all times or you could be stranded in the dark! Keep that water tank as full as you can to fling those bombs and work your jackhammer! And watch out below; a long fall can really, really hurt, in more ways than one; when you’re scrapped, you give a share of your gathered valuable resources, mined from the very rock itself, to the powers that be that you may return to life.

I would most definitely recommend this to Metroidvania fans like me, and those who are enthralled by the SteamWorld; for more from this awesome franchise, also check out Heist, a tactical turn-based action game!

最后的BOSS如果你想要无伤通过，那你就要对自己所掌握的所有操作技巧了如指掌才行！
这同时也是这代技能设计的优秀之处。
唯一不足之处就是BOSS战稍微少了一些，但看在设计了这么多精妙的挑战洞穴的份上，也无可厚非了。

收集要素中的收藏品(遗物)，一个很容易想到的设计居然在一代里没有，令人觉得有些费解。
此外，虽然说加了一些些沙盒的元素，但其实说透了只能算是传统的"选关"。
实际上还是和一代一样一本道的通关方式了。

但是话说回来，一本道有什么不好的，花个15-20个小时，将一款游戏100%通关，不留任何遗憾的开启下一段游戏之旅。
在当今各种游戏层出不穷，未玩的游戏多如牛毛的情况下，这种精致的一本道设计让我感觉非常舒服。

Image & Form，这家公司目前出的三个作品都非常优秀，我现在已经迫不及待想要看看你们还能将这群蒸汽机器人玩出什么花样了！
或者在这之前，出一个DLC满足我这饥渴的探索之魂吧！！！
                        --Wingo

Un jeu sympathique, fluide et agréable à explorer. 
C'est un réel plaisir de miner pour pouvoir s'acheter des améliorations !

En revanche, même si je suis assez fan de ce genre de jeu (les "métroïdvania") j'avoue avoir été un peu déçu par la difficulté trop basse (boss final tombé du premier coup) et par le manque de durée de vie (jeu fini en 6h).

La durée de vie peut être prolongée si l'on recherche tous les trésors (j'ai environ trouvé 50% des secrets sans trop chercher), mais cela reste un peu juste pour moi. 

En résumé, laissez-vous tenter si vous voulez un petit jeu agréable et simple. Si vous cherchez un peu plus de profondeur et d'immersion, je vous recommande de vous tourner vers d'autres titres comme "Ori and the blind forest" ou l'excellent "Hollow Knight" .

Edit : Je tiens à préciser que je n'ai jamais joué au premier de la série.

Have played games for 20+ years, variety of types and this I can say it has some of the most frustrating and irritating puzzles I have ever come across.

Unless you find wasting time doing the same puzzles over and over again because of slight hand eye coordinative miscalculation.... Enjoyable..... I suggest not buying this game. 

Perhaps many would laugh at the failed persistence but in my honest opinion.... some of the puzzles in this game are too frustrating to finish the game.

So save yourself the money if you are on the fence and somewhat easily irritated with silly unforgiving puzzles.

For Example, pushing a lever and having to fly from wall to wall only using the grappling hook with Not entirely time accurate natural ability refreshes, while being expected to jump and grapple from wall to wall in Several Rooms of which MOST surfaces contain buttons that shuts the door at the end the lever at the beginning opened, essentially, touch a surface and press a button... go back to the beginning, press the lever and try again and again and again and again and again and again.

Not my idea of a good puzzle. If it is to you, by all means purchase the game, if it does not sound like fun, save yourself the money.

With multiple 'sequence-breaking' routes possible, this game is probably the closest thing I've played to Super Metroid in about a decade. No zone is truly "gated" off from the rest of the map, and exploration is rewarded instead of punished. The first time I beat the game I was missing about half of the power-ups due to the route I took. I didn't test it, but i think it is possible to beat the game without beating any boss besides the final.

It's also quite enjoyable to play the game as intended, though the characters and story are rather weak.
Don't try for the hardest two chievos unless you want to spend a weekend routing and practicing movement exploits.

37476331.review:
Maybe the best game in the steamworld serie. 8.52/10 
This episode connects the story of the other games, but you don't have to play them in order ( they are not in chronological order in the first place). It's pretty cool to see things get tied together. 

Great level design, great controls and lots of cool moves for that little robot. It's pretty deep (no pun intended). 
The side kick is pretty funny though overall the dialogues arent that exciting ( not the strongest point in the other titles either). 

Overall if you enjoy platforming and exploration, you'll probably like it. 
If you played the first steamworld dig, its all the same stuff but much better. And the metroidvania aspect is much more developped! 

Finishing the game without searching for secrets or doing every challenge rooms ( maybe the funnest part of the game) probably takes 7-8 hours. Took me 13h to 100% it and it felt satisfying, it ended when I was ready to move on. :)

37431576.review:
Так как однажды стал поклонником творчества "Image & Form", однозначно ждал эту игру ещё с первых анонсов. Вторая часть невероятно насыщенная по сравнению с первой, но, к сожалению, не намного длиннее. Скорее всего специально не делают эпично длинные игры оставляя пробелы для будущих предисторий и продолжений. Кто бы мог подумать, что оказывается между Dig и  Heist не только одна вселенная, но и одна история. Ещё из Heist было понятно судьбу планеты разлетевшейся по всему космосу. В эпилоге Dig 2 очень мощный спойлер для тех, кто играл в Heist. Теперь остаётся только ждать ещё пару лет до выхода нерасказанной истории между уничтожением и процветанием в космосе.

За всё игровое время не обнаружил ни одного бага. Это же насколько нужно быть идеалистом в своём хобби. Вы не подумайте, что отрицательные отзывы (да, они существуют) ссылаются на проблемы игры. Нет, просто некоторым игрокам сложно понять как играть в такие игры, от того и недопонимания. Здесь вылезано всё настолько, что Вы просто обмазываться будете от прохождения этой игры.

Разработчик невероятно тонко продумал хардкор игры. Вот держите сложность поменьше, но легко не будет. А если хотите посложнее, то найдите 3 потерянных братьев и соберите достаточно реликтов, что уже можно считать хардкор, так как секреты не так очевидны порой. Наградой будет 4 дополнительных опции усложнения процесса игры, хотя можете и не включать.

Ещё одно большое спасибо за ещё одну потрясающую игру. Браво!

Steamworld Dig 2 is a charming side scrolling platformer/metroidvania/puzzle game that evokes those fun feelings I got playing games like Mario and Rayman back in the day. That whimsical, charming feeling that you get when you play something that just feels fun. 

I love how good the movement feels and I love the thrill of finding a new power deep in the mines that helps you get around even quicker. I love finding secrets and collecting resources as I dig to power myself even further. 

With wonderful music and excellent art to back it up, steamworld dig 2 is an easy recommendation to anyone that was a fan of dig dug, spelunky, motherlode, or any of those countless digging flash games online.

37240760.review:
Finished the game.

Good points that I liked within the game:
-8 hours gameplay, Focused a lot on finding all the secrets.
-Great map details in some areas.
-Nice impleted Skills that have a purpose to each map.
-Puzzle hidden caves that are different and fun to complete.
-Many secrets (Idol items) to find and rewarding with custom upgrades you can unlock.
-Creative level desiged maps.
-1 spooky map that actually made me anxious to play.
-Addicting type of gameplay to make people complete the game.

Bad Points that I didn't like in the Game:
-Lack of bosses, could have been great to get the special upgrades after a mini-boss and actually feel rewarded.
-Dull interactions between NPC's, Could been added funny context or cool scenes to feel more immeresed into the story.
-Lack of good Story elements, I didn't paid any attention to the story only until the end. bored me quite fast from the start, The storyline didn't felt like it was making an impact on the game essence.
-Felt somewhat a bit short even tho' I played as complitionist and tried to find all the secrets. (Isn't really as bad as it sounds, just a feeling I had)

Overall summary:
The Game is great, worth the price and I had more fun than most games I played recently.
I would say the Bad Points I wrote don't have a big impact on the game experience, but rather would make the next SteamWorld Dig Game with those changes even more exciting to play and more enjoyable.

Rating: 8 / 10

I would buy the game again for the same price if the story was different without a doubt.

36856011.review:
I had pretty high expectations for this game after having a blast playing Image & Form's previous games - namely SteamWorld Dig and SteamWorld Heist. And oh boy did this game deliver and then some!
I tend to stay away a bit from platformers (yeah, I am not really good at games requiring quick reflexes) but this game just captivated me from the beginning and I could not pull myself away from playing it.

Beautiful graphics, great sound effects and background music, intense and tight platforming that provides so many fun ways to navigate around and fight enemies, puzzle sections to make you feel smart, just the right amount of hidden treasures... the list of good points for this just goes on and on.

I've seen some people complain about the game length and yeah, this game is not as long as the Skyrims and Witcher RPGs out there. But then, this game has no boring filler stuff that just exists for the sake of extending playing time. Just chock full of tight, interesting, fun content.

Will definitely be looking out for Image & Form's next project, whenever that may come. Thank you to the developers!

36554021.review:
Thanks to the developer and publisher of Steamworld Dig 2, Image & Form, for creating an excellent  game for me to escape, explore and enjoy.

The first  games on PC in the Steamworld series, Dig and Heist, were pretty good but like all good developers Image & Form doesn't reinvent the series but they made a good series into a great one by making it better in every way.  Steamworld Dig 2 is a beautiful, addicting, polished and most importantly fun game that is easily one of the best games of the year.

Steamworld Dig 2 is a platform jumping, digging, exploration, action game. You play as Dorthy, an ally from the first Dig game, who is trying to find her friend Rusty. While looking for Rusty you are also hired to help out the local town in trying to find the answers behind mysterious earthquakes. If new to the series, the world of Steamword Dig is set in a steampunk western setting that is inhabited solely by robots. Language is incoherent but the look of each character and their dialouge exlemphies each ones personality. The story is simple to follow and not a burden and was I surprised by the emotional ending.  

In the game you will be exploring a pretty massive underground world. There are a lot of diverse environments to explore and each with their share of treasures, challenges, hazards and enemies. At first you will only be given your trusty pickaxe but later tools including a jack hammer, water cannon, hookshot and the best accessory ever, the jetpack will be awarded for completing missions. All of these awesome tools are upgradeable with cash earned from excavating  gems and additional features are upgraded with cogs. Cogs for the most part are in secret areas or in puzzle rooms scattered around the map. There is also a vendor in town who sells cogs but its unnecessary to ever purchase any. There are also secret objects(42 total) that when a certain number is found you will be rewarded with a blueprint. These also unlock additional upgrades for your equipment. All of this is so rewarding and returning to the store with a full backpack of gems never gets old. I will say its kind of a slow start as the opening level gems in the area do not pay, but once you go deeper unlocks begin to happen more frequently.   

Graphically Steamworld Dig 2 looks beautiful and ran perfectly at 1080P(Ultrawide) max settings. Its almost looks like a bright shiny saturday cartoon and movement and controls are excellent. Sound is also really good especially when hitting away at all those rocks, enemies and that rewarding sound of when collecting coins. The soundtrack is also impressive though near the end i was a little tired of the one track that plays constantly when you are just simply exploring. 

Steamworld Dig 2 is a rare game on the PC that achieves the unthinkable and thats the deserving rating of polished. Its execution, gameplay, controls, levels and world are near flawless. Its probably the best released game i've played in recent memory without any needed patch or DLC needed. One of the best games this year, easily. 

Played on max settings 1080P ultrawide MSI R9/390 with no problems

Positives

Polished in every way
Beautiful diverse World to explore
Exploration is rewarding
Jetpack 
Ultrawide supported
Large variety of enemies
Fun boss fights
The right amount of challenge, not too easy/ difficult

Negatives

Not a lot of missions
Some upgrades unnecessary
No maps to buy showing secret locations

36538410.review: The metroidvania approach gets kinda boring at  the beginning due the lack of interesting upgrades and poor customization system for itens etc. things get way interesting in mid/late game although, mainly because of infinite jetpack and other features you will be able to unlock by solving lots of puzzles inside caves collecting cogs and idols, changing the gameplay a lot giving you an addictive experience.

36486523.review:
This is what all sequels should strive to be, improving all the strong points from its previous installement, fleshing it out until you obtain a nice polished gem (Hah, mining jokes). But it's not just that. It also gets rid or tone down of most if not all of the flaws of SteamWorld Dig 1, and to top it all off, adds a lot of new things to enjoy. If you enjoyed the first game as much as i did (a lot), there is no hesitation to have, this one is such a massive improvement it'd be criminal not to get it.

Incredibly fun, and not as short as a few reviews make it sound like. It's well worth the price. Easily a dozen hours or more if you like to complete most/all of the game and not blast through the story.

Music and ambience are quite good, though not the most memorable soundtrack.

Art is really pleasant to look at.

Story isn't going to blow your mind, but it's pretty enjoyable and engaging enough, lot of interesting dialogues which is much more than what Steamworld Dig had to offer.

The gameplay is really all about block digging, selling, upgrading, and metroidvania elements, much like the first one, but it is deceivingly satisfying and addictive, and not like a borderline abusive relationship you'd have with an MMORPG. Where this aspect shined before, SWD2 turns it up tenfold. You also get rewarded a lot more for killing enemies.

The content is also much more rich in terms of upgrade, map design, characters, secrets, creative challenge rooms and so on. The only real downside you could argue about is the lack of enemy diversity, which is a recurring problem. Still, the replayability/lifespan of the game is higher than i had expected, and i'm really not regretting the price tag. It's a bit less linear than the first one, which can be confusing but gives you a nice sense of freedom.

The difficulty is also a bit disappointing if you want a challenge, but it's not much of an issue if you're in it for the relaxing digging aspect.

Technical side, controls and options are still perfect. No bugs i can remember of either.

Overall, SteamWorld Dig 2 is one of my 2D loves alongside, Terraria, Ori, Hollow knight, and a few others.

This game deserves no less than an 8/10.

36474336.review:
Steamworld Dig 2 is a nice sequal that improve on pretty much everything from the first game. It's probably not a game that will be on many peoples best of 2017 list at the end of the year, but for the price it's a pleasent metroidvania. I liked the first game well enough but preferred the gameplay from Steamworld Heist but this was a nice diversion until we get that sequal. 

The environments are more varied, the upgrades are no longer just objectively better stat boosts and there is more of a story this time. The core gameplay loop is the same, dig for recourses and use the money on upgrades with ocotional puzzle room where you might find new items or abilities. Pretty much standard metroidvania fare but it's well designed. If you liked the first one, then this is a solid recommendation. You should almost certainly like this even more, but even if you didn't there are significant improvements that might change your mind.

36459548.review:
Eu fiquei anestesiado ao jogar Steamworld Dig 2, principalmente pelo pacote completo que os desenvolvedores trouxeram ao fazer essa sequência, que expande e complementa o universo "Steamworld".

[h1]A história e os personagens:[/h1]
Nesse jogo, você controla "Dorothy", acompanhada pelo seu 'amigo', Fen a procura do desaparecido "Rusty". É um fato inegável, a dorothy não carrega o mesmo carisma de rusty e é pouco explorado o seu desenvolvimento, mas em compensação Fen é um personagem carismático, dúbio, sádico e com um senso de justiça e moral meio turvo. 

A história do jogo no entanto consegue ser melhor do que a primeira, trazendo boas perguntas a serem resolvidas e deixando o jogador intrigados nos mistérios que cria durante a narrativa. Narrativa esta que possui um ritmo pulsante, nunca deixando o jogador cansado ou desfocado no seu objetivo principal: Encontrar Rusty.

[h1]As mecânicas e a jogabilidade:[/h1]
Quanto ao gameplay, em boa parte é um metroidvania, isto é, você pode andar, correr, pular, se segurar na parede e usar habilidades especiais que vai ganhando conforme o avanço do gameplay, como atirar uma minibomba, usar um jetpack nas botas,  dentre outras. Há também a mecânica de exploração e mineiração, isto é, quão longe na mina você alcança, a fim de faturar mais e aumentar seu progresso.

O jogo possui também um  pouco de mecânicas de RPG, pois você escolhe quais upgrades quer fazer [e pode ficar alternando constantemente, gerando várias combinações possíveis, como um personagem mais forte, mais resistente, mais rápido para perfurar, etc]. Outra coisa bacana do gameplay é que há vários desafios a serem realizados, cada um testando uma habilidade diferente sua, algumas em questão de timming, outras em precisão, mas todas são diferentes e testam uma skill a qual você vai obter no gameplay; há também vários itens a pegar que acrescentam no lore da história e são bons coletáveis, acrescentando umas horas de gameplay.. É uma jogabilidade desafiadora e engajante em mais de 8 horas de campanha [para completar TUDO vai em média umas 13h]. 

[h1] Os gráficos, a trilha sonora e aspectos técnicos: [/h1]
Os gráficos do jogo são lindos, 2D estilizados num universo que combina o stempunk com faroeste, é visualmente cativante e traz você para o universo do jogo, além de fazer um ótimo uso de sombras, e poeira no vento, dando um certo destaque à direção de arte do jogo.

A trilha sonora é viciante, em especial o tema de "Archea" e o tema de "El Machino".


 A movimentação é bem fluida e dinâmica, em especial da dorothy que é mais ágil e leve que o rusty. Steamworld Dig 2 é um jogo bem otimizado que não causa quaisquer problemas técnicos por ser muito bem desenvolvido.



A IA do jogo é ligada no modo "kill kill" e não há muito que se comentar. A física do jogo, apesar de ser meio surrealista, é boa, você toma dano e pode até morrer dependendo da queda, toma dano em ambientes com lava ou ácido.

Sobre bugs, o jogo crashou apenas 1x e o máximo de bugs que encontrei foram alguns inimigos que morreram, mas "continuavam lá", mas foi algo bem raro.


[h1]Conclusão e Nota: [/h1]
Steamworld dig 2 supera seu antecessor em termos de jogabilidade, apesar de ter uma protagonista não tão interessante, há um roteiro promissor e belíssimos gráficos.

Nota: 8,9/10.

[h1]Para mais análises, apoie-nos seguindo nosso [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30823884/]Curador[/url]

36430738.review:
[h1]HAI-HO, HAI-HO, SI TORNA A LAVORAR![/h1]

ADORO la saga di Steamworld. Il primo "Dig" è un inaspettato Metroidvania che mi ha tenuto incollato fino al 100% del completamento; "Heist", il secondo episodio, è un simpatico strategico a turni alla Xcom dalle belle musiche, favolosi cappelli e missioni impegnative. Entrambi hanno assolutamente qualcosa da dire e questo terzo capitolo non è da meno.
La trama riprendere esattamente alla fine del primo gioco: [spoiler] Rusty, il protagonista, è riuscito a sconfiggere il Voltbot a capo dei Vectron, ovvero una razza di robot elettrici disposti ad assorbire ogni Steambot nella collettività ("La resistenza è inutile"). In chiusura lo si vede allontanarsi nel deserto con gli occhi accesi di una strana energia blu. [/spoiler]
La piccola Dorothy, che col padre dirige il negozio di oggetti acquistabili e a cui Rusty aveva salvato la vita all'inizio del gioco, non vedendolo tornare, decide di andare a cercarlo divenendo l'eroina del nuovo capitolo.

La struttura di Steamworld Dig 2 è di fatto identica al primo (scavare, guadagnare gemme con cui comprare oggetti e trovare potenziamenti per poter proseguire gli scavi), c'è però un'evoluzione: ogni oggetto acquistato con le gemme avrà un potere dormiente che potremo attivare incastonandoci degli ingranaggi speciali. Ogni ingranaggio potrà essere rimosso e riposizionato a piacere, trasformando così Dorothy (Dot per gli amici) in un robot configurabile e il gioco in un mezzo RPG, una via di mezzo tra i primi Final Fantasy (per i poteri legati agli oggetti impiegati) e Diablo (per le gemme da incastonare).
Le mappe sono ancora più grandi del primo Dig e le situazioni/enigmi/segreti leggermente più impegnativi. Ci saranno sempre brillanti in posizioni rischiose, oggetti dimenticati imboscati chissà dove e tesori da scovare, ma tutto più in grande, insomma.
Ne vale la pena? Assolutamente sì. Soprattutto se avete apprezzato il primo capitolo. E poi così scoprirete come siamo giunti... al secondo (no spoiler!!!)! ;-)

36427435.review:
SteamWorld Dig 2 é jogo indie de aventura/plataforma com fortes influências do gênero metroidvania. Desenvolvido e distribuído por Image & Form, mesma equipe responsável pelo sucesso de SteamWorld Dig e SteamWorld Heist. O título foi lançado oficialmente no dia 22/set/2017 e até o momento desta review estava com 97% de analises positivas na plataforma Steam, consolidando o sucesso da franquia. O game está bem produzido, conseguiram manter a essência dos anteriores ao mesmo tempo que deram um toque inovador nesta sequência.

Não tenho como explicar com exatidão todos os eventos em torno da história sem que revele alguns spoilers, por isso vou resumir de uma maneira bem breve e que não entregue algo além do que já se encontra na descrição do jogo em sua página de compra. Aqui você volta há assumir o papel de um steambot – como nos outros jogos, caso já tenha jogado – que é basicamente um escavador/explorador, a trama realmente começa quando se depara com um centro comercial muito antigo que vem sofrendo com tremores e terremotos fora do comum.

O jogo consiste em muita exploração, mas não se engane, ação também é um elemento que não falta, assim como pequenos chefes que podem dar alguma dorzinha de cabeça – no normal, no fácil é.... Fácil – com o tempo você pode fazer upgrades para explorar novas áreas e conseguir novos acessórios para facilitar sua vida, mas tenha muito cuidado, quanto mais fundo você ir, mais armadilhas mortais vai encontrar e inimigos poderosos vão estar lhe aguardando.

SteamWorld Dig 2 é fácil de jogar, seus comandos seguem padronizados e durante o jogo ele mesmo vai lhe ensinando – um tutorial básico para cada nova função que libera – é possível jogar no teclado, até porque muitas pessoas já se adaptaram ao mesmo, porém com o controle em mãos é uma experiência sempre nostálgica e o mapa de botões está muito confortável, acredito que não será preciso mais do que alguns minutos para lembrar todas as funções. Visualmente o game está impecável, assim como sua trilha sonora que é um verdadeiro espetáculo. Posso afirmar que se trata de um título que atrai tanto os mais jovens como tem conteúdo para chamar atenção dos gamers de longa data.

A história é razoavelmente grande, não é nada complexa, porém é bem explorada no decorrer dos eventos, só é uma pena que não tenha legendas em português – e que a comunidade deve cobrar – pois em 2017 um jogo, mesmo que indie, deveria ter legendas ao menos em PT/PT. Fiz diversos testes de desempenho, alterei funções e tentei forçar alguns erros, mas o jogo se saiu muito bem em tudo, sua otimização é certamente um ponto alto, mesmo computadores bem fracos podem desfrutar deste maravilhoso game e sem perder a qualidade visual.

Sinceramente? É um jogo fantástico e merece todas as análises positivas que vem recebendo da comunidade, é difícil achar pontos ruins num jogo que claramente foi desenvolvido com muito empenho e carinho pela equipe responsável, SteamWorld Dig 2 é mais uma amostra que embora o gênero de mundo aberto esteja ganhando mais espaço do que nunca, os games de plataforma possuem muita força e podem surpreender ainda mais.

[h1]Destaques:[/h1]

+ Otimização;
+ Controles simplificados;
+ Visual e trilha sonora deslumbrantes;

[h1]É preciso atenção:[/h1]

- Adicionar legendas em PT/BR ou PT/PT;

[h1]Bugs encontrados:[/h1]

# Nenhum;

36406666.review:
I'm starting to really like Image and Form, I hadn't played the original one but I played Steamworld Heist and decided to give this one a go aswell, based on that. Was not let down. The game is very fun to play and does a good job to compel you to keep playing. 

I had a little issue with the verticality of the digging mechanics, being only at the very end do you get equipment that lets you traverse upwards. I guess it's just part of the balance. 

Combat felt adequate and the bosses were fairly easy. The game's challenge is however challenging you make it. The diggin mechanics are made difficult by enemies also destroying terrain, often having rocks fall down on your resources. So a methodical approach nets you more rewards. There is also the option to turn on blueprints that make the game harder.
It's not really a heavy storydriven game, Rusty merely serves as a McGuffin to keep the plot going forward, aswell as the game. But this didn't bother me in Steamworld Heist either, the gameplay makes the game. 

Performance wise it runs excellent. 144fps locked without a hitch and fast loading times. And the game looks amazing, especially if you have a vibrant panel.

Can't wait what Image & Form bring next. Indie is definitely the way to go these days, what with AAA only making lootbox infested tripe.

36397846.review: Steamworld Dig 2 ist ein mehr als gelungener Nachfolger zum ersten Teil. Es geht darum, dass ihr in der Gestalt des Dampfroboters Dorothy einen alten Freund sucht. Wer den ersten Teil gespielt hat, weiß genau, wen ich meine. Ihr erkundet ein gigantisches Höhlensystem und findet viele Erze und "Verbesserungsrädchen" diese Rädchen sind dazu da, um bestimmte Upgrades die ihr gefunden habt, nochmal zu modifizieren. Wo wir schon bei Upgrades sind, das Spiel ist so aufgebaut, dass ihr an bestimmten Stellen nur mit bestimmten Upgrades weiter kommt. Ihr müsst auch manchmal an alte Orte zurrück gehen wenn ihr bestimmte Upgrades habt. Dieses Spiel ist wirklich ein Metroidvania. Das finde ich gut, denn ich liebe Metroid. Es gibt auch an jeder Ecke Geheimgebiete mit Rädchen oder einem Artefakt. Was den Wiederspielwert enorm erhöht, weil man beim ersten durchspielen ohne 100% Lösung auf keinen Fall alles findet. Das Spiel bekommt von mir eine 8,5/10 Wertung und eine Kaufempfehlung. Keine 10/10 weil das Spiel leider kurz ist. Für das erste durchspielen habe ich nur 7 Stunden gebraucht. Aber das Spiel solltet ihr euch auf jeden Fall mal anschauen. Glaubt mir, die 20 Euro sind es Wert!

36331838.review: Интересная и хорошо сделанная, но короткая.

36329885.review:
SteamWorld Dig (2) ist ein absolutes Juwel unter den PC spielen. Mit viel Metroivania, liebevollem Retro-Steam-Punk Design, und einem ebenso schlichten aber süchtigmachenden Spielprinzip hat es mich voll begeistert. Der zweite Teil macht sogar alles besser, was der erste Teil noch nicht so perfekt umgesetzt hat.

Im Grunde genommen läuft es auf einen Mix hinaus aus Story, graben, verkaufen, aufrüsten, graben, erforschen, Story, verkaufen, aufrüsten, graben... graben... graben... bis der Arzt kommt :D

Die ersten Playthroughs dauern etwas (8-16 Stunden), wenn man selbst nach allen Geheimnissen sucht. Und die sind hingegen andere Spiele hier wirklich auch selbst findbar, dank späterer In-Game "Helferlein".

Um jedoch alle Achievements zu erhalten muss man einen anspruchsvollen Speedrun hinlegen, bei denen man eine volle Gold-Wertung erhalten muss in allen 4 Disziplinen (Zeit <4 Stunden, Geheimnisse 100%, Credits >15000, Anzahl Tode =0). Das war sehr fordernd, aber nicht unmöglich, da man auch den leichtesten Schwierigkeitsgrad spielen darf. Selten lasse ich mich zu Speedruns hinreissen - hier hat es dem ganzen neuen Pepp gegeben udn Spass gemacht.

Man darf auch ein wenig Schummeln, was die Tode betrifft - solange ihr das Spiel verlasst, bevor ihr die Todesmeldung quittiert mit OK, kann das Spiel den Tod nicht speichern (das geht aber nicht bei allen Spielszenen) ;)

Mit Gamepad spielt es sich deutlich angenehmer, und der ist fast für den Speedrun Pflicht. Dank dem verbesserten Gamepad Support den Windows und Steam erst vor kurzem für den Playstation 4 Controller eingeführt haben, kann ich den Controller endlich im vollen Umfang nutzen ohne InputMapper zu verwenden um einen XBox-Controller vorzugaugeln - klasse.

36304109.review:
È a prima vista un plagio totale: tutte le meccaniche sono ereditate da Dig Dug, Boulder Dash, Spelunky, Rick Dangerous, oltre che da Metroid e Castlevania. Ma presto ci si accorge della fusione perfetta fra azione, esplorazione, strategia, comandi perfetti, grafica ammaliante.

Niente picchi di difficoltà artificiosa come in Ori and the Blind Forest o respawn selvaggio come in Hollow Knight: il miglior Metroidvania moderno è questo, come ben evidenzia la rivista Edge. 

Una cosa proprio bella è la possibilità di sperimentare liberamente i potenziamenti. I nemici sono ben assortiti, sebbene le boss fight vere e proprie siano relativamente poche.

La localizzazione in italiano è eccellente, a parte alcuni typos che ho segnalato agli sviluppatori e che forse verranno sistemati in occasione di un'eventuale prossima patch.

Ora devo proprio andare, sono ancora immerso nelle profondità di questo capolavoro e al momento non ho alcuna voglia di riaffiorare in superficie.

Voto: 9.2 su 10 - Ipnotizzante

36200469.review:
SteamWorld Dig 2 is a sequel to adventure-platformer that involved going underground and mining precious ores. In this game, the niece of the hero from the first part is trying to find him. The game expands the ideas from the first part: you still need to dig through the caverns, seek valuable resources, sell them and upgrade your gear while trying to uncover some plot mystery. But it’s all done in a way bigger scale.
	
	I’m not talking about the size of the map (it has also increased), but the functionality as well: the arcade elements are there, but the game feels more like metroidvania now: apart from simple digging deep below, you get new locations like cultist temple, windy plains, human town. This all add flavor to the game and enhance the story.

	Speaking about the story: it still feels pretty straightforward, but my impression was that it is not the main focus of the game. What the game succeeds at is aesthetics and progression, coupled with engaging gameplay. First, let’s talk about the aesthetics: the style is cartoonish and colorful, but that gives a very strong charm to the characters of the game. The backgrounds differ much more than they did in the first part, making locations distinguishable and much more memorable. 

	The main gameplay loop is at its height: gathering metals, ores, valuables deep down below is done in a very formidable way. The player is gradually introduces to new game features, be it grappling hook, drill or remote bombs. Those mechanic introductions are followed by new tasks that player needs to solve. It indicates that SteamWorld Dig 2 has a great game design. In the end, the game presents challenges, gives you the tools to solve them but does not throw a correct solution straight at your face, giving you time to think and fulfillment from solving riddles. The digging itself is very pleasant, the pickaxe sound + the rock crumbling are really well-done. It’s addictingly fun to go back to town and see the numbers grow.

	Speaking about the riddles, there are special challenge rooms located around the map. If you finish them – you get cogs to upgrade your gear with various adjustments. Those rooms are well thought out, you won’t need to dig much there, but focus on solving situations that often require the use of newly-gained mechanic. On a negative side, this dilutes the digging experience (if you are more into that). To counter that argument, those challenge rooms are not exactly mandatory.
	
	Also, the game is going to be as difficult as you want it to be. Apart from normal difficulty settings, there are special equipment addons that can make enemy battles much more challenging.

	Honestly, I usually list the cons at this point but I could not find them here. Some mention the game is too short, but the completionists will find things to do nonetheless (challenge rooms + getting all secret objects that give special blueprints, there are 42 of them).

	Overall, the game is a highly polished and pleasing experience and I can confidently recommend it to fans of the genre, especially to the people who loved the first part.

[h1]Wholesome & Lovely[/h1]


For over a week it was my perfect after work activity. A bit addictive, but on the other hand so nice that I didn't want it to end, so I rationed it to entertain me for over week.
The storytelling gives us a bit of background, but can be described as the weakest part. Luckily this deficiency is outshined by the gameplay mechanics. The controls are  finetuned, and you quickly develop a smooth flow.
The game progresses very nicely when it comes to upgrades and such. During the last two hours or so I felt a bit overpowered, but beside that the game feels well balanced.
It took me ~ 17 hours two finish it, and there is still stuff left to do.

At least on the PC the release was a bit outshined by Cuphead, but a plattform lovers should feel blessed that there are still devs out there who release such high quality games.
Support the developers and buy this game if you love platformers.

36110537.review:
별 탈 없이 잘 계승된 땅굴파기 메트로배니아.

행방불명된 전작의 주인공인 러스티를 찾기 위해 그의 동료였던 도로시가 이번에는 직접 곡괭이를 들고 지하 세계를 탐험한다. 땅을 파고 들어간다는 컨셉 상 다른 메트로배니아 게임과는 다르게 위에서 아래로 나아가는 진행 방식이 인상적인 메트로배니아 게임이다. 이 때문에 동일 장르의 다른 게임과는 판이한 진행 양상을 보인다. (미스터 드릴러를 RPG처럼 즐긴다고 생각하면 편하다.) 그래도 조작도 원활히 잘 되고 난이도도 적절하다. 자원을 모아 장비를 갖춰야하기 때문에 극초반이 살짝 지루하게 느껴질 수 있지만, 이 극초반만 잘 넘기면 상당히 재밌게 즐길 수 있을 것이다.

3D로 바뀐 그래픽과 주인공이 무뚝뚝한 채굴로봇 러스티 대신 말괄량이 여자(...겠지, 아마) 로봇 도로시로 바뀌었단 점을 빼면, 전작과 크게 다른 부분은 없다. 땅을 파고 들어가는 게임플레이부터 전투 방식과 장비 강화, 줄거리의 진행 양상까지 거의 모든 게 유사하다고 봐도 좋을 정도. 전작과 별로 다른 부분이 없다고 할 수 있겠지만, 이걸 다른 말로 하자면 그만큼 전작의 장점을 잘 계승해왔다는 소리도 된다. 좋은 점이라면 굳이 고치기보단 적당히 유지하고 보수하는 편이 더 좋으니 말이다.

단 하나의 지하 구역만 준비되있던 전작과는 다르게, 스팀월드 디그 2에는 총 세 개의 구역이 준비되어 있다. 각 구역마다 각기 다른 컨셉을 보이고 있어 플레이할 맛이 나고, 텔레포트 시스템도 잘 갖춰져 있어서 구역 간 이동도 매우 편하다. 다만 구역이 다양함에도 불구하고 각 구역의 길이가 긴 건 아니다보니 보통 4시간에서 6시간이면 엔딩을 볼 수 있을 정도로 플레이타임이 그리 긴 게임은 아니다. 이 역시도 전작과 동일한 부분.

그래도 엔드 컨텐츠라고 할 수 있는 추가 즐길거리들도 꽤 충실하게 준비되있다. 총 42개의 아티팩트와 이것들을 다 모으면 도전할 수 있는 최후의 챌린지 던전, 그 밖에 각종 숨겨진 요소들이 준비되있으며, 시간/돈/사망회수/비밀의 4가지 조건아 따라 엔딩 후 받게 되는 랭크 시스템이 준비되어 있어 야리코미와 스피드러너들을 위한 즐길거리도 잘 마련되있다. 게임 본편이 조금 짧게 느껴지더라도, 이것들까지 감안한다면 준비된 것은 꽤 많은 게임이라고 할 수 있겠다.

전작에 이어 '땅을 파고 지하로 들어간다.'라는 컨셉을 아주 잘 살린 메트로배니아 게임. 전작과 동일한 구석이 많은 게임이니 전작과 함께 즐겨주면 더욱 좋다.

35832009.review:
Just an upfront preamble before the actual review. The company who made this game, Image & Form Games, sent me a free copy of the game and requested that I make a YouTube video covering it. They did not request a review be written, I'm doing that on my own accord. My video covered first impressions of around the first thirty minutes of the game, and is linked below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKIQh9wRYT4&ab_channel=darkchiron

[b]Overview:[/b] The game itself is a 2D platformer where you use a pickaxe to mine ever deeper into the Earth in search of a lost friend. As you progress you acquire new abilities, such as a bomb launcher to blow up things, and a hookshot to allow you to pull yourself to walls, ceilings and floors. You will also acquire upgrade cogs, that will allow you to access extra functions for the abilities you unlock, such as making your pickaxe do more damage to enemies. You will find gems that you can sell to make your abilities overall more powerful, like making your pick axe mine through blocks faster or giving you more bomb launcher ammo. There is also a levelling system in the game, and each level makes your gems sell for more money, and allow you to further level up your abilities. The game is littered with dungeons, smaller areas that serve as a place to challenge yourself within the game and find upgrade cogs and artifacts. There are also a number of secret areas to find throughout the map.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Overall the gameplay is fun and engaging. The game in general is very easy, outside of one or two sections that can pose a challenge. The secret trials unlocked at the end of game by collecting every artifact is also a welcome challenge if you're looking for it. Besides a (kind of) boss at the start and the final boss, there are no other major enemies within the game, just minor enemies to serve as obstacles as you make your way through the game. If you're looking for a game to really challenge your abilities, this game probably won't do it. But if you're just looking for a fun platformer that you can enjoy progressing through and exploring for secrets, then this is the game for you.

[b]Story:[/b] There is a story, but it doesn't get incredibly in depth. The basic story is that you are Dot, a robot in search for her friend who went missing after he defeated Vectron and saved the world in the previous Steamworld Dig game. You quickly find a new friend to join you on your journey, as you dig further down into the mines and discover that a sinister plot is unfolding. The story is pretty interesting, but it doesn't really seem to be the focus of the game. It serves more as a reason for you to keep exploring and moving through new areas of the game. But in that respect, the game does do a very good job of making sure you know where you're supposed to be going by making sure it is marked on the world map.

[b]In Closing:[/b] I played enough of the game to beat it with all artifacts collected and access the hidden trials at the end of the game. Having played it all, I can fully endorse this game to anyone who enjoys 2D Metroidvania style games. If I had purchased it for $20, I would have felt it was money well spent given I enjoyed all 12 hours it took me to fully complete the game.

35668774.review:
[I]SteamWorld Dig 2[/I] is another hit from Image & Form, building on the success of the first game in pretty much every way. The game sees players taking control of Dorothy, a companion to the first game's protagonist, Rusty, as she seeks to discover what has happened to Rusty, and develops into a full-blown 'Metroidvania'-style exploration game while retaining the mining and wealth accumulation from the original [I]SteamWorld Dig[/I].

While it's easy to drop in and out of the game for brief stints of gameplay, it's very easy to lose yourself in the game's core mechanics, which make for a very relaxing, engrossing and ultimately satisfying experience, as you gradually expand and improve Dorothy's abilities. New to this over the original game are a range of additional bonus abilities that can be selected (and swapped out at will) - the range of these expanding as more core upgrades are obtained/purchased - which themselves also encourage further exploration to gather more of the upgrade 'cogs' that each bonus ability costs to enable.

Dotted throughout as you dig deeper through each of the the game's key areas are a number of secondary cave areas, the majority of which present a challenge or puzzle or some kind. There's an impressive range of different scenarios offered by these, each of which is very enjoyable to solve, rewarding upgrade cogs and other materials. For those who want to challenge themselves, there's good potential for replaying the game with a speedrunning approach, or limiting the abilities that you allow yourself access to, but even without this the game has a good length.

This is all presented with some attractive graphics and animation, making for an excellent overall package - highly recommended!

35632682.review:
I'd like to start and say that I was not a fan of the original Steamworld Dig.  I do enjoy the concept and the asthetic of the games (and I did enjoy Steamworld Heist), but Dig had gameplay issues I could not get past.  That being said, SD2 is a lot of fun and I enjoyed it from start to finish.

You are a steambot named Dorothy who is in search of her friend Rusty, the bot from the original SD.  You are digging in the mines to find him, all while collecting ore, which you sell to upgrade your gear.  You can also find cogs and artifacts which you use to activate mods on your equipment, which changes how they work.  

Moving around the underground was my biggest problem with SD, and they have made it much, much easier to get around in SD2.  It's fun to collect and go back to town to sell stuff to upgrade your items.  The story is cute, but not fantastic.  Graphics and sound are adequate, but nothing too special.

So I definitely recommend SD2 if you were a fan of the original, as this is better in every way.  And if you just want a fun action adventure type game (I hate to use the term Metroidvania, because it means so much to me, but it fits a little here), definitely check this out.

I just finished this game after a 12 hour spurt.  It was so fun that I finished it in only two sessions, which is hard for me to do nowadays.  I rarely can sit for a game for much more than an hour or 2.  This game has it all.  Exploration and character upgrades, in metroidvania style, mixed with a digging game - the latter of which was something I've never been interested in, yet this game does it in such a way that made it a blast

As I mentioned there are tons and I mean TONS of upgrades for your character.  Even when I thought I was surely done finding them, I just kept finding more.  And that's not to mention that each item itself can be upgraded multiple times, which unlocks various perks.

I am so impressed with this game.  Anyone likes those old school exploration and leveling games will love it.  The art direction is fun and quirky.  It's not overly difficult, but then I grinded so much that I was just about maxed with everything except the jackhammer.  

Amazing job development team!

[h1] 곡괭이를 든 메트로베니아 [/h1]

  Steamworld Dig 2는 아마 9월에 발매된 게임 중 가장 인상깊었던 인디 게임일 것입니다. 사실 전작을 플레이해본 적도, 그 이름을 들어본 적도 없었기에 이 게임의 발매 소식을 듣고는 기대보다는 걱정이 앞섰습니다. 하지만 다행히도 게임 플레이를 시작한 지 고작 20분 만에 그러한 걱정은 다 날라가버리더군요.

  이 게임은 기본적으로 곡괭이를 든 메트로베니아입니다. 중반부부터는 여러 다른 도구들을 이용할 수 있지만 기본적으로는 적도 곡괭이로 잡고 길도 곡괭이로 내며 보석도 곡괭이로 캡니다. 그렇다고 그저 눈 감고 아무 땅이나 막 파대면 안 됩니다. 맵에는 여러 적들이 오묘한 위치에 산재해 있고 또 플레이어를 깔아뭉개어서 일격에 산산조각내는 돌덩어리들도 곳곳에 있기 때문입니다. 마인크래프트를 생각해보면 이는 게임에 깊이와 재미를 더해주는 요소가 될 수 있습니다. 물론 마인크래프트도 좋은 게임이지만 어쨌든 마인크래프트에서는 가끔씩 용암 소리가 들려올 때를 빼고는 그저 멍하니 땅만 파면 되었던 반면 스팀월드 디그 2에서는 절대 그러면 안 됩니다. 그렇게 조심조심하며 여기저기 흩어져 있는 보석들을 캐내는 게 이 게임 플레이의 95%를 이루고 있습니다.

  이렇게 모은 보석들은 마을에 가면 웬 꽃게 아조씨한테 주고서 돈으로 교환받을 수 있고 이 돈으로는 곡괭이나 배낭 따위의 장비들을 업그레이드할 수 있습니다. 맨 처음의 기본적인 장비들은 너무 흑흑하기 때문에 이 업그레이드가 이 게임 플레이의 최대 관건이라고도 할 수 있겠습니다. 더 좋은 곡괭이를 사거나 보석이 들어갈 공간을 늘려주는 질 좋은 배낭을 산 뒤 땅을 파러 광산에 들어가고, 그러다 보석 좀 모이면 다시 마을로 가 돈으로 바꾸어서 장비를 업그레이드하고,,, 뭔가 듣기만 해선 게임 플레이가 지루하고 반복적일 것 같을 수도 있겠으나 지루해지려고 할 때마다 튀어나오는 새로운 맵과 몬스터들은 시종일관 게임을 흥미진진하게 해줍니다.

  그런데 이 게임이 지루하지 않은 또 다른 이유가 있습니다. 바로 플레이 타임이 생각보다 짧다는 점입니다. 검색을 해보니 평균 플레이 타임은 5시간 내외고 저 역시 4시간 만에 게임을 끝마쳤습니다. 온갖 수집 요소들을 다 모으면은 플레이 타임이 10~15시간 정도로 늘어난다고는 하지만 그래도 5시간은 좀 짧다고 느껴질 수 있을 것 같습니다. 제 생각에 이 게임의 플레이 타임이 짧은 이유는 물론 볼륨 그 자체의 문제도 있겠지만 무엇보다도 난이도가 좀 많이 쉽기 때문인 것 같습니다. 이 게임이 메트로베니아를 표방하고 있다고는 하지만 길 찾기가 꽤 쉽습니다. 사실 게임을 하다보면 제작진들이 의도적으로 난이도를 낮추려고 노력했다는 걸 알 수 있습니다. 투사체들을 피하는 퍼즐이나 사방에 가시가 돋아나서 제트팩으로 통과해야 하는 구간 앞에다가는 무조건 체력을 채워주는 하트를 갖다 놓는 게 그 예입니다. 그나마 어려웠던 건 최종보스전이었던 것 같네요.

  스토리는 그냥 스토리가 있다는 걸 느낄 수는 있는 수준이었고, 로봇들의 디자인은 조금 아쉽습니다. 사실 저는 스팀월드라고 대문짝만하게 박아넣은 게임이길래 로봇들 디자인에 대해서도 꽤나 큰 기대를 가지고 있었습니다. 하지만 그 기대에는 미치지 못 하는 것 같아 조금 실망스러웠습니다. 그래도 이건 개인차에 따라 다르게 느껴질 수 있는 부분이니 직접 플레이 영상 같은 것을 보고 판단하는 게 좋을 것 같습니다.

  이 게임의 또 다른 장점으로 빼놓을 수 없는 게 바로 아트워크와 사운드트랙입니다. 저는 게임의 사운드트랙을 잘 구매하지 않는 편인데 이 게임을 하면서 사운드트랙을 꼭 사야겠다는 생각이 들더군요. 아트워크 또한 무척 아름다워서 정글 파트에 돌입하게 되면 그냥 마음이 흡족해집니다. 물론 이 정글맵은 발광이 너무 심할 때가 간혹 있어서 블럭 타입 구분이 잘 안 갈 때도 있습니다.

  그래도 저는 한 가지 아쉬웠던 게 곡괭이로 길을 만들어나갈 수 있다는 점을 이 게임은 잘 못살린 것 같았습니다. 이 게임의 장르는 메트로베니아인데 메트로베니아는 어려운 길찾기가 특색인 장르라고 개인적으로 생각합니다. 그런데 여기다 주인공에게 곡괭이를 들려주었다면 주인공이 정형화된 길을 따라가는 것이 아닌 직접 새로운 길을 개척하게 만들 수도 있지 않았을까요? 이 게임은 스스로 길을 개척해나간다는 느낌이 없습니다. 제가 알기론 한 가지 목표에 도달하기 위해선 한 가지 길과 방법밖에 없었습니다. 인디 게임이니 너무 많은 것을 바라면 안 되긴 하겠지만 그래도 꽤나 아쉽더군요.

  저는 개인적으로 플레이 타임이 짧더라도 재미만 있으면 얼마든지 적정가에 게임을 구매하는 사람입니다. 그리고 제 생각에 스팀월드 디그 2는 재미도 충분하고 가격도 적정선에 있는 것 같습니다. 괜찮은 인디 게임을 하고 싶은데 좋은 아트워크와 사운드트랙, 그리고 재밌는 플레이를 보장받고 싶다는 사람은 이 게임을 당장 구매해서 해보길 바랍니다.

7.3 / 10

Almost 6 hours to complete the campaign. I'm proud that I played the first recently because otherwise I would have missed the sequel. If you go for the main goals the game is sort but if you want to go for the 100%, it might take double of what I played.

I don't know if they will go for a third game or they will connect the universe with SteamWorld Heist in a sequel of that game all I can say is that its been a great time with this game and is worth the time and money without question. Now is time for SteamWorld Heist.

SteamWorld Dig 2, such an awe inspiring sequel to the first. The first game had it's ups and downs, and I expected this one to be very similar to it. Oh boy was I wrong, SWD2 keeps all the same spirit, but with brand new 'upgrades' for your character. Throughout the game I kept expecting there to be an upgrade that was the same, and non of them were. I congratulate the dev team for making the second game different to the first in more than just the art style. 

If you want to play this game, I HIGHLY recommend playing the first game, because otherwise you wouldn't understand any of the story. 

Time for the pros and cons!
Pros:
- Completley new upgrades
- New 'cog' system
- Revamped graphics
- Runs probably too well on my potato laptop
- Takes about 7-10 hrs to complete casually

Cons: 
- Sometimes the gameplay can get kind of repetivtive, just mining and hitting creatures
- Some secrets aren't explained very well (But I guess that is why they are secrets)

If you want to get this game, I hope you enjoy it!

35509618.review:
Some gamers didn't seem to find the gameplay of the first game all that fun and engaging, but they might find this sequel enjoyable.  The core gameplay mechanics have been improved and it feels more like a platformer. You have more abilities and it is more action-oriented than the first.  There is a broader skill set that you can practice and hone your skills.  They really expanded upon all the fundamentals of the game while keeping some of the core concepts from the first.

The RPG elements are better, the story is better, the characters are better, the abilities, game mechanics, size of the maps, and length of the game are all just better.

If you found the first game boring, you should definitely give this a try because it might be fun enough for you to enjoy now. For others who enjoyed the first game like myself, you'll most likely love this sequel!  Runs beautifully in Linux and with a gamepad, great couch game, well done devs! <3
